Author: Lumbi#8378
Content: @PTYX how so?

Author: PTYX#6840
Content: they launched services that became ubiquitous

Author: PTYX#6840
Content: what cryptocurrency, good for the earth, or "decentralized" project has done that?

Author: PTYX#6840
Content: but in order to argue about whether they are good or not, we'd need to establish the meaning of "good"

Author: Lumbi#8378
Content: @PTYX  ... the public good?

Author: PTYX#6840
Content: what is the public good

Author: PTYX#6840
Content: the dictionary says

Author: PTYX#6840
Content:
```Economics
a commodity or service that is provided without profit to all members of a society, either by the government or a private individual or organization.
"a conviction that library informational services are a public good, not a commercial commodity"
2.
the benefit or well-being of the public.
"the public good clearly demands independent action"```

Author: PTYX#6840
Content: is UNESCO for the public good?

Author: Lumbi#8378
Content: @PTYX or the benefit of the many (rather than the few)?

Author: PTYX#6840
Content: ok, point me to an example of a "good" company

Author: Lumbi#8378
Content: drinkable water is a "public good" (vs. ground water polluting factories).

Author: PTYX#6840
Content: hmmm

Author: Lumbi#8378
Content: a good company benefits more than it harms

Author: PTYX#6840
Content: Nestle has clean water

Author: PTYX#6840
Content: or drinkable water

Author: PTYX#6840
Content: i think the definition of "good" is very nuanced and almost impossible to argue because it's subjective

Author: Lumbi#8378
Content: it's profit motive could be against the public good, if it uses lobbyists to block environmental legislation that would make tap water drinkable...

Author: PTYX#6840
Content: why not have "good" lobbyists

Author: PTYX#6840
Content: seems to me that it's the only way politicians get off their ass is with a good lobby

Author: Lumbi#8378
Content: lobbyists could be used for good... if the economic system allows for adequate participation on that level...

Author: Lumbi#8378
Content: ...how 'democratically participatory' are 'economics' ?

Author: Lumbi#8378
Content: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Percy_Bysshe_Shelley

Author: joe2x4#5987
Content: Why do we need politicians again? Insanity is trusting the people who create the problems to fix the problem. It seems that politicians were societies fix to the Byzantine general problem. Can't trust each other so we elect them under trust that they work to benefit society. But politicians are scum humans. Can't trust them either. We can trust POW  however.

Author: joe2x4#5987
Content: Blockchain voting WILL be a human right soon.

Author: joe2x4#5987
Content: Budgets WILL be doled out via smart contract.

Author: joe2x4#5987
Content: Transparency and Auditability WILL follow.

Author: PTYX#6840
Content: It's naive to think that all of humanity's problems will be solved with trust less or decentralized systems. There's still the human element in everything aspect of society that you must deal with.

Author: PTYX#6840
Content: Just from my perspective it seems most people need or are molded to trust others to do things on their behalf. In order to really change things you'd need to tear down the establishment.

Author: PTYX#6840
Content: And even then, you'd have quasi-establishments pop-up to represent a certain people.

Author: Lumbi#8378
Content: Incremental steps into futurity; why can't that look more civilised than in yesteryears? Technology is a miracle if done right and can do much to repair even past damages.

Author: Lumbi#8378
Content: general consensus, popular policies, infrastructure improvements, etc.
